title: The Company of Captain Dirck Jacobsz Rosecrans and Lieutenant Pauw
titles: The Company of Captain  Dirck Jacobsz Rosecrans and Lieutenant Pauw, Amsterdam, 1588
description: Schuttersstuk met het korporaalschap van kapitein Dirck Jacobsz Rosecrans en luitenant Pauw, Amsterdam, 1588. Dertien schutters van de Voetboogdoelen, staande naast elkaar, ten voeten uit, de meesten gewapend.

acquisition.creditLine: On loan from the City of Amsterdam

iconClassDescription: warfare; military affairs (+ citizen soldiery, civil guard, citizen militia)

Metz, 'Becoming a Virtuoso Painter: Cornelis Ketel's Portrait of Adam Wachendorff and Homo Bulla', in: Making Art in Tudor Britain, Abstracts from Academic Workshops (2007-2008), internetpublicatie op: http://www.npg.org.uk/research/programmes/making-art-in-tudor-britain/workshops/workshop-3-abstract-11.php

Ann Jensen Adams, 'Civic guard portraits : private interests and the public sphere', Nederlands Kunsthistorisch Jaarboek (1995), p. 172, 173, 184.
E. de Jongh, Openbaar Kunstbezit 7 (1963), nr. 1, afb.
P.T.A. Swillens, 'Beelden en ledepoppen in de schilderkunst', Maandblad voor Beeldende Kunsten (1947), p. 282, afb. 25.
F. Schmidt Degener in Zeitschrift für Bildende Kunst 59 (1925/'26), p. 175.
F. Schmidt Degener in Onze Kunst (1916), p. 83.

longTitle: The Company of Captain Dirck Jacobsz Rosecrans and Lieutenant Pauw, Cornelis Ketel, 1588
subTitle: h 208cm × w 410cm

label.title: The Company of Captain Dirck Jacobsz Rosecrans and Lieutenant Pauw
label.description: Thirteen self-assured officers of the Amsterdam militia, the city’s armed civic guard, are portrayed here. From 1580, at the initiative of William of Orange, the old militia guilds were refashioned into civic guards organized along military lines. The officers were recruited from the upper levels of society. The dark muzzled dog at right contrasts comically with the jaunty little lapdog at centre jumping up on its owner’s legs.
